title: Trouble for the world's richest company sends a shiver down Aussie spines
text:
The Australian share market is down almost 1.2 per cent in early trade, dragged down by a sharp plunge on Wall Street overnight.

The ASX200 hit a four-month low for the Australian market , opening 0.8 per cent down after shaving 64.8 points to hit 8571.6.



The US stock market sank overnight as Nvidia and other "superstar" stocks created by the frenzy around artificial intelligence technology dimmed some more.

A trader works on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange on Monday (Tuesday AEST).Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg (Bloomberg)

In the US, the S&P 500 fell 0.9 per cent and pulled further from its all-time high set late last month.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 557 points, or 1.2 per cent, and the Nasdaq composite sank 0.8 per cent.

Nvidia was the heaviest weight on the market, as it’s often been in its last couple of tumultuous weeks. The chip company fell 1.8 per cent, while losses for other AI winners included a 6.4 per cent slide for Super Micro Computer.

Other areas of the market that had been high-momentum winners also sank. Bitcoin fell below $US92,000 ($141,000) down from nearly $US125,000 last month, for example.

That helped drag down Coinbase Global by 7.1 per cent and Robinhood Markets by 5.3 per cent.

Jensen Huang, chief executive officer of Nvidia Corp, during the keynote address at the Nvidia AI summit in Washington, DC, last month. (Bloomberg)

Critics have warned US stock market could be primed for a drop because of how high prices have shot since April, leaving them looking too expensive. Critics point in particular to stocks swept up in the AI mania, which have been surging at spectacular speeds for years.

Despite its loss overnight, Nvidia is still up 39 per cent for the year so far after it doubled in price in four of the past five years.

That has Wall Street’s spotlight on Wednesday (Thursday AEST), when Nvidia will report how much profit it made during the summer.

AI stocks have surged as much as they have because of expectations that they’ll produce huge growth in profits. If they fail to top analysts’ expectations, that would undercut one of the big assumptions that’s driven the US stock market to records.

Such high expectations extend beyond tech stocks, even if they are toughest for AI darlings.

READ MORE: ﻿ Pauline Hanson plans to woo Barnaby Joyce to One Nation over a hearty dinner

Aramark fell 5.2 per cent after the company reported a profit for the latest quarter that fell short of analysts’ expectations.

The company, which offers food and facilities management for schools, national parks and convention centres, also said it expects an underlying measure of profit to grow between 20 per cent and 25 per cent this upcoming year.

While relatively strong, that was less than what analysts had been forecasting.

That helped offset a rise of 3.1 per cent for Alphabet, the parent company of Google, which jumped after Berkshire Hathaway said it built a $US4.34 billion ownership stake.

Berkshire Hathaway, run by famed investor Warren Buffett, is notorious for trying to buy stocks only when they look like good values while avoiding anything that looks too expensive.

Another source of potential disappointment for Wall Street is what the US Federal Reserve does with interest rates.

The expectation had been that the Fed would keep cutting interest rates in hopes of shoring up the slowing job market. Wall Street loves lower rates because they can give a boost to the economy and to prices for investments.

READ MORE: ﻿ TPG confirms Sydney death after customer was unable to contact triple zero

But questions are rising about whether a third cut for the year would come out of the Fed’s next meeting in December, something that traders had earlier seen as very likely.

The downside of lower interest rates is that they can make inflation worse, and inflation has stubbornly remained above the Fed’s 2 per cent target.

Fed officials have also pointed to the US government’s shutdown, which delayed the release of updates on the job market and other signals about the economy.

With less information and less certainty about how things are going, some Fed officials have suggested it may be better to wait in December to get more clarity.

Now that the shutdown is over, the government is preparing to release September’s delayed jobs report on Thursday (Friday AEST). That could create further swings for the market.

Data that’s very strong would likely stay the Fed’s hand on rate cuts, while figures that are very weak would raise worries about the economy.

In 2026, the Fed is likely to cut interest rates only in response to a slowing economy instead of trying to cut ahead of it, according to Barry Bannister, chief equity strategist at Stifel. That’s not as good an environment for stock prices, and Bannister said the “Fed’s ‘free lunch’ is over".

In the bond market, the yield on the 10-year Treasury edged down to 4.13 per cent from 4.14 per cent late Friday.

In stock markets abroad, indexes fell modestly across much of Europe and Asia.

Tokyo’s Nikkei 225 slipped 0.1 per cent after the government reported that the Japanese economy contracted at a 1.8 per cent annual pace in the July-September quarter.

title: Too late to stop 1000 years of deadly heatwaves, Aussie scientists say
text:
The world is facing a thousand years of deadly heatwaves regardless of whether humanity reaches net zero emissions - but delays in achieving that target will only make things worse.

Researchers working at the ARC Centre of Excellence for 21st Century Weather, and CSIRO, ﻿modelled what the next millennia of heatwaves would look like, based on the assumption global net zero would be reached between 2030 and 2060.

Heatwaves were shown to be systematically hotter, longer and more frequent the longer net zero is delayed, and they may be exacerbated by long-term warming in the Southern Ocean even after net zero is reached.

READ MORE: Australia at risk of destructive weather not seen for a decade

The world faces 1000 years of deadly heatwaves. (Getty)

Most trends showed no decline over the entire 1000 years of each simulation, indicating that heatwaves do not start to revert back towards pre-industrial conditions even when net zero is reached, for at least a millennium.

Some regions even displayed heatwaves of significantly increasing severity when net zero occurs by 2050 or later.

Professor Sarah Perkins-Kirkpatrick of the Australian National University, the lead author of the paper , said the research showed achieving net zero would not necessarily immediately improve conditions for future generations.

Researchers say urgent work to reach net zero earlier is needed. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

"While our results are alarming, they provide a vital glimpse of the long-term future, allowing effective and permanent adaptation measures to be planned and implemented," she said.

"It's also vitally important that we make rapid progress to permanent net zero."

Co-author Dr Andrew King of the University of Melbourne said adapting to this future would be the work of "centuries, not decades".

"Investment in public infrastructure, housing, and health services to keep people cool and healthy during extreme heat will very likely look quite different in terms of scale, cost and the resources required under earlier versus later net zero stabilisation," he said.

title: Fake claims about pension age rising spread online
text:
A﻿ false claim circulating online that the pension age in Australia will rise to 68 this month has been republished by Google AI.

The false information, published by HIIT5158.com.au, claims the "official retirement age" in Australia will move from 67 to 68 from November 10, 2025, affecting anyone "born on or after 10 November 1958".

The information was then picked up by Google AI and was presented in its Overview for some searches.﻿

READ MORE: Australia at risk of destructive weather not seen for a decade

A screenshot of false information circulating on Facebook last week. (Facebook)

Australia does not have an official retirement age.

Australians can retire at any age if they have the financial means to do so.

Superannuation can generally be accessed when an individual reaches "preservation age", which is ordinarily somewhere between 55 and 60 depending on when you were born.﻿

Currently, to be eligible for the government's Age Pension you must be 67 or older.

READ MORE: The troubling sunscreen data that will set off alarm bells ﻿

The false claim was still presenting as part of Google AI's Overview on Monday morning. (Google)

A spokesperson from the Department of Social Services said "the government has no plans to change the Age Pension age".

"The Age Pension eligibility age is 67, however you may apply up to 13 weeks earlier," the spokesperson said.

Current and correct information on the Age Pension and all social security payments is available on the Services Australia website.

READ MORE: Brad Battin ousted as Victorian opposition leader ﻿

(HIIT5158)

In response to questions from 9news.com.au, Google said it had investigated the issue and the response had been fixed.

"We aim to surface relevant, high quality information in all our Search features and we continue to raise the bar for quality with ongoing updates and improvements," a Google spokesperson said.

"When issues arise including if our features misinterpret web content or miss some context, we use those examples to improve and take appropriate action under our policies."

title: Rachel helps breast cancer survivors, but she's not allowed to show her work
text:
A Queensland cosmetic tattoo artist who helps breast cancer survivors says it is almost impossible to share photos and videos of her work on social media.

Rachel Cahn, who runs Tinted Love in Noosa, specialises in creating tattoo areolas for clients who have undergone mastectomies and no longer have nipples.

Being able to provide realistic-looking, 3D areola tattoos for cancer survivors was deeply meaningful, Cahn said.

READ MORE: ﻿ Dozens of schools to close over asbestos play sand fears

Cosmetic tattooist Rachel Cahn is calling for change from social media companies in dealing with images and videos of breast cancer survivors. (Tinted Love)

"This art is not just about aesthetics; it's often the final step in helping survivors to reclaim their bodies and restore their sense of hope and dignity," she said.

Areola tattooing is a relatively new procedure available for breast cancer survivors and Cahn said she was therefore keen to let as many women as possible know about it.

However, social media platforms such as Facebook, Instagram and TikTok were constantly banning her photos and videos due to them being flagged as showing nudity, Cahn said.

"Social media platforms can't distinguish the difference between nudity and art," she said.

"I can't post anything on TikTok, they don't really allow any of my work."

Likewise, Cahn said photos she posted to Facebook showing areola tattoos were often banned, after which she needed to go through a time-consuming process to have them reinstated.

Rachel Cahn is seen tattooing an areola on a client. (Tinted Love)

Cahn said other restrictions had been placed on her accounts, such as Instagram banning her from posting live videos for 12 months and Facebook blocking her from inviting people to join her page.

The cosmetic tattooist said she also suspected her accounts had been "shadow banned".

"Shadow banning is where you don't come up in people's feeds," she explained.

"You're not on the 'explore' page. People try and type in your name, and it doesn't come up."

The actions of the social media giants appear to directly contradict their policies on allowing photos and videos of breast mastectomies for education and advocacy purposes.

"We agree that undergoing life-changing experience and that sharing photos can help raise awareness about breast cancer and support the men and women facing a diagnosis, undergoing treatment or living with the scars of cancer," Facebook says on its website.

"The vast majority of these kinds of photos are compliant with our policies."

It is understood that the automated processes used by social media platforms to detect nudity, including nipples, is unable to distinguish between﻿ real and tattoo areolas.

Nine.com.au reached out to Meta, the owner of Facebook and Instagram, for comment but did not receive a response before publication.

A spokesperson for TikTok said the platform had worked with Cahl to reinstate two videos which were "incorrectly moderated by our automated systems".

﻿"TikTok's Community Guidelines do not allow nudity or body exposure, but we do allow some content that falls within our limited exception categories," the spokesperson said.

Cahn said she was exhausted by the process of trying to fight the social media companies simply to show her work.

"It is tiring, and I'm wanting women to know that I'm here and what I do, but it doesn't get seen by anyone, and I get all these bans and restrictions and flags," Cahn said.

"And it is so hypocritical because then you see all the hate speech and the violence on social media.

"Even Instagram says they don't allow photos of buttocks, and I'm just like, come on, that's an absolute joke, every second woman is in a string bikini."

Frustrated, Cahn has started a Change.org petition calling for social media companies to reform the rules for cosmetic tattooists who work with cancer survivors.

"The guidelines need to be changed so that cosmetic tattooers can post these images, so that breast cancer survivors are aware that this service is available.

"I have a lot of women that actually come in here and they say that they didn't even know the service was available until I posted something in one of the Facebook groups."

title: AFL draft club by club: Every team's picks and potential targets
text:
The 2025 AFL draft is nearly here, and clubs will be putting the finishing touches on their plans in hopes of uncovering their next superstar.

Check out what picks each team will be bringing to draft night and which players could be in their sights.

The AFL draft will be held over two nights on November 19 and 20 and you can follow ABC Sport's live blog on both.

Adelaide

Picks 16, 48, 55, 61

The Crows fought extremely hard to keep their top pick, refusing to send it to Brisbane for Callum Ah Chee.

Adelaide would love to get its hands on South Australian captain Dyson Sharp, but he's likely to be well out of the Crows' draft range, as will fellow Croweater Sam Cumming.

However, the Crows could still wind up with a South Australian in the form of Mitch Marsh, a talented forward prospect.

Eastern Ranges halfback Oskar Taylor has also been linked to the Crows.

Brisbane

Picks 17, 23, 44, 51, 57

What a brilliant position the Lions find themselves in for the second year running.

Daniel Annable is a ready-made midfielder who will make the Lions even stronger. (Getty Images: Josh Chadwick)

Just a few months after winning their second straight premiership, the Lions are poised to add the player some draft experts rate as the best prospect in this year's class in Daniel Annable.

Annable is an AFL-ready midfielder who is poised enough to jump straight into most midfields in the competition. The only problem for him is that Brisbane's midfield is not any normal midfield to just slide into, as Levi Ashcroft found out.

The only question for the Lions is just how early a bid on Annable, an academy prospect of theirs, will come. The timing of the bid, which many expect to be in the top five, will likely see most of the Lions' draft picks get eaten up.

Carlton

Picks 9, 11, 43, 54

The Blues are preparing for the exciting acquisition of key defender Harry Dean, a father-son prospect who could easily attract a bid inside the top five overall selections.

The Blues will do whatever it takes to match a bid on Dean, but will likely also try to get creative to ensure their night doesn't end there. That may mean trading pick nine, or 11 — or possibly both — to make sure it can keep a selection in this year's first round and possibly even secure another for next year.

If they do manage to keep a first-rounder this year, the Blues might like to look at someone like key forward Aidan Schubert and hope he slides. With Charlie Curnow no longer at the club, Schubert would fill a need and represent great value outside the top 10.

Tom De Koning's departure may see Carlton look for a new project ruck, and Louis Emmett would fit that bill. Or they could go completely the other way and look at electric small forward Lachy Dovaston, who would be an instant fan favourite.

Collingwood

Picks 39, 45, 56, 58, 67

Collingwood's hand is not particularly compelling, but it will come into this draft with its sights set on one specific player at least.

Zac McCarthy is tied to the Pies through their Next Generation Academy and is a raw but exciting tall of great potential. McCarthy could yet receive a bid inside the first round, such is his potential, but the Magpies would be expected to match it.

How early that bid comes will determine the rest of Collingwood's draft, as the Magpies may only be able to select two more players should enough of those picks be swallowed up by matching an offer for McCarthy.

Father-son prospect Thomas McGuane does not look likely to be picked up by the Pies in the national draft, as they opted against nominating him ahead of the cut-off. A rookie spot is not out of the question for McGuane.

Essendon

Picks 5, 6, 21, 27, 30

Essendon is in a position to add the best available talent that falls past West Coast and Richmond.

Dyson Sharp is a tough contested midfielder and a strong leader at a young age. (Getty Images: Josh Chadwick)

Players such as Sullivan Robey, Dyson Sharp and Sam Cumming have been most strongly linked to the Bombers with their first two picks, while Xavier Taylor would also fit nicely as an attacking intercept defender.

The Dons have two academy players in the draft, Adam Sweid and Hussein El Achkar, and haven't fully committed to drafting both just yet.

Sweid is tipped to be picked at the back end of the first round, and could land at the Bombers with one of the picks in the 20s.

Fremantle

Picks 20, 47, 64, 72

The pressure is on Fremantle more than ever to have some tangible finals success after a disappointing elimination final exit at the hands of Gold Coast this year.

Freo possesses a strong midfield and a number of game-changers forward of the ball, but its key defensive stocks can be vulnerable at times, often seeing Josh Treacy swing back into defence in tight situations, compromising the structure up the ground.

Key defender Blake Thredgold from Sturt would be a nice addition for the Dockers here. Standing at 194 centimetres, Thredgold projects as an athletic defender who can become a prolific interceptor.

Geelong

Picks 19, 40

Predicting Geelong's movements at the draft is a tricky exercise, though it is normally its later picks that bring the big surprises.

With a first-rounder at their disposal, the Cats will take best available as their list needs are few and far between. Speedy winger Harley Barker seems an excellent fit at Kardinia Park, and he would represent good value after an ACL injury halted his rise in 2025.

A young tall forward like Archie Ludowyke may also appeal, and you can generally expect the Cats to fire off some bids on NGA talent rated around that pick.

Hunter Holmes, brother of Max, would be a sentimentally favoured pick among Cats fans later in the draft.

Gold Coast

Picks 15, 18, 24, 28, 29, 36, 52

Once again the Suns come into a draft with peace of mind and a guarantee of a strong haul. In fact two of the best five players in this draft are guaranteed to be Suns by next Wednesday night.

Dylan Patterson is an excitement machine off half-back. (Getty Images: Josh Chadwick)

Zeke Uwland and Dylan Patterson are products of the Gold Coast academy, and even if bids come on those two inside the three or four picks on the night — which is very possible.

Beau Addinsall is another highly regarded member of the Suns' academy and will garner a bid at some point, possibly late in the first or early in the second round. Jai Murray is another that Gold Coast will not want to let slip.

The Suns will be engaged in some pick swaps early on night one to ensure they are covered points-wise for any eventuality. Theirs is a very different draft experience to most clubs.

GWS Giants

Picks 12, 35, 73

As a team full of big-bodied midfielders and burly key forwards, the Giants are in the market to add some speed and craftiness to their list, particularly in the forward half of the ground.

Lively small forward Lachy Dovaston is a player who GWS would love to get its hands on, and one that would fit well with the rest of the list.

Sam Grlj is a chance to be selected by Richmond with one of its two top-10 picks, but if the Tigers do not take him, then he could potentially slip all the way down to the Giants' range.

Keeping with the zippy forward theme, the Giants could snap up Latrelle Pickett, the cousin of Melbourne's Kysaiah, who has proven to be one of the late draft bolters this year.

Hawthorn

Picks 10, 22, 59, 66

The Hawks will begin draft night with a top-10 pick, and though that will slide back considerably once the bids come in, it is still a great result for a club fresh off a preliminary final.

Midfield improvement has been Hawthorn's stated aim this off-season, but there is unlikely to be any stand-out candidate for that area by the time its selection comes up. Jacob Farrow, who has shown promise in the middle despite playing mostly off half-back this year, could appeal in that range.

The Hawks tried to gain access to midfielder Ollie Greeves via their NGA this year but were denied, so he may still be in contention, more likely for the Hawks's second pick than the first.

And then there's Lachy Dovaston. A Nick Watson clone, the thought of pairing those two in a forward line is one that should be encouraged — though perhaps there is a limit how many cheeky, mulleted goalsneaks one team can contain.

Melbourne

Picks 7, 8, 37, 63, 65

The Demons are guaranteed to bring some quality in with their two top-10 picks, though they will slide just beyond 10 after bids come in early, but are somewhat at the behest of the clubs ahead of them.

Sam Cumming is a versatile midfielder who can do the tough stuff and get forward to kick goals. (Getty Images: Mark Brake)

Depending on which way West Coast, Richmond and Essendon go, Melbourne could have a raft of gun mids to pick from, a selection of talls or the draft's most dynamic little blokes.

Sam Cumming would be a dream pick for the midfield, and Dyson Sharp would fill the Clayton Oliver hole instantly. Aidan Schubert would be a fantastic boost to a struggling forward line, while Sam Grlj, Lachy Dovaston or bolter Cameron Nairn would certainly get fans through the gates.

The Demons can hardly go wrong with their two picks. They will be content to wait and see who is still available and pick their favourites from there.

North Melbourne

Picks 25, 26, 46

The Kangaroos are also in talent-acquisition mode, and will look to draft the best available player with their first pick.

It will be interesting to see whether the Roos are able to swing a draft-night trade by packaging their first two selections together to potentially move into the teens. If they do, expect a tall to be the target with Aidan Schubert and Blake Thredgold both good options.

If the Roos stay put, South Australian midfielder Harley Barker will come into their calculations.

Port Adelaide

Picks 49, 69

The Power will be out of action into the latter stages of this year's draft due to previous trades.

Port has a high-powered midfield and will be keen on bolstering its key position departments, particularly in defence.

If it is willing to swing some of its existing big men around the ground, a prospect such as Murray Bushrangers forward Liam Hetherton would be nice selection at 49.

Hetherton's teammate Riley Onley could also be of interest, given he is a 195cm midfielder, a point of difference compared to other mids in the class.

Richmond

Picks 3, 4, 38, 68

The Tigers are in a tantalising spot courtesy of last year's draft-night trade with North Melbourne netting them a second top-five pick.

Sullivan Robey is a late developer whose strength and power in the midfield and forward line have seen him rocket up boards. (Getty Images: Asanka Ratnayake)

Richmond will almost certainly bid on many of the players that are tied to other clubs such as Dylan Patterson, Daniel Annable and Zeke Uwland, should they remain on the board.

If West Coast doesn't opt for big man Cooper Duff-Tytler, it would be hard to see Richmond pass on him, given his blend of size and athleticism is rare. Otherwise the likes of Sullivan Robey, Sam Cumming and Xavier Taylor will appeal.

The Tigers also face a decision on whether to use one of their high picks on speedster Sam Grlj, who played for their VFL side late in the year.

St Kilda

Picks 50, 62, 70

On paper the Saints do not have much to work with this year, the price of their aggressive spending spree during the trade period.

Kye Fincher is a member of the Saints' NGA and will draw a bid at some stage, most likely on night two, and the Saints would be keen to match.

But there are also whispers the Saints might have something else up their sleeve. Could their 2026 first-round pick be up for grabs if it was to get them a look at a target earlier on night one? And could that player be Jevan Phillipou, brother of Mattaes?

Expect the unexpected when it comes to St Kilda this off-season.

Sydney

Picks 31, 32, 42, 60, 71

The Swans have academy prospect Max King to keep an eye on and he has been tipped to have one of the widest ranges in the draft.

King could land anywhere as high as pick 20 and as low as the mid-30s, a spot which would be ideal for Sydney.

Sydney could also package its first three picks to potentially move into the high teens or low 20s if a player it ranks highly internally falls on draft night.

Half-back prospect Harry Kyle is also tied to the Swans, as is Lachie Carmichael. It remains to be seen whether all three get to the club.

West Coast

Picks 1, 2, 13, 34, 41

Clubs have shown interest in West Coast's top two selections, but it seems most likely that the Eagles keep them both for themselves on draft night.

Cooper Duff-Tytler is a ruck-forward with a unique athletic profile and excellent skills. (Getty Images: Asanka Ratnayake)

Willem Duursma is near enough to a lock to be selected with the top pick, and is a talent worthy of the mantle. At pick two the Eagles have to balance their many list needs — do they opt for the next-best regarded talent in ruck-forward Cooper Duff-Tytler, or look to belatedly bolster the midfield with Dyson Sharp, Sam Cumming or Sullivan Robey?

Most expect Duff-Tytler to be the Eagles' man with that pick, and though he may be a slower burn his ceiling is sky-high.

The third first-round pick currently sits at 13, though the Eagles are said to be keen to move that up if they can. If they can't, a punt on injured winger Harley Barker could be of interest, or a more speculative look at Josh Lindsay or Noah Hibbins-Hargreaves.

NGA prospects Tylah Williams and Koby Evans and father-son Charlie Banfield could all receive bids, and ideally the Eagles would see to securing all three.

Western Bulldogs

Picks 14, 33, 53

The Bulldogs find themselves in an interesting position within the first round of the draft and are well placed to scoop up a slider or take their pick from a diverse range of prospects.

Big-bodied midfielder Ollie Greeves is a good chance to still be on the board at the Bulldogs' pick, they could look at zippy half-back Oskar Taylor or dynamic mid-forward Noah Hibbins-Hargreaves.

But given the Bulldogs' well-publicised need for key defensive support, Blake Thredgold should be highly considered if he is available. A tall but athletic full-back, Thredgold would need a couple of years to fill out but is already dominant in the air and combative at ground level.

title: More schools to reopen Wednesday with updated closure list due tonight
text:
More schools will reopen in Canberra on Wednesday with a list of current closures to be updated this evening.

The ACT government shut 70 public schools on Monday after several coloured sand products were recalled by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC).

Dozens reopened today, but 25 remained closed and 16 were partially closed.

At this stage, 19 schools will remain closed in the ACT tomorrow.

Fifteen schools are expected to be partially open tomorrow, but the ACT Education Directorate will also provide a further update on all school closures at 6pm.

ACT Yvette Berry said it would still be several days before all schools were reopened.
