title: Audit finds Townsville council overrode tender process in another integrity blow
text:
Townsville City Council (TCC) breached Queensland regulations by directly appointing a contractor without calling for tenders, an external audit has found.

Under Queensland's Local Government Regulation 2012, a local government cannot enter a contract worth $200,000 or more in a financial year or over the term of the contract, without inviting written tenders first.

A Queensland Audit Office (QAO) report released on November 13 found that a council employee who recommended and approved the contract, based the recommendation on incorrect costings.

"The estimated total contract value was based on one year of expenditure only, despite the contract term being three years," the QAO wrote.

" The final contract amount also exceeded both the quoted amount and the approved recommendation to award. "

Townsville City Council is providing refresher training to staff after the procurement breach. (ABC North Qld: Chloe Chomicki)

It comes 12 months after the council overpaid departing executives despite citing financial challenges that led to the council hiking rates, cutting subsidies and doubling parking fees.

In September, it was revealed half of TCC's projects in the three years leading up to 2024 were, on average, 26 per cent over budget.

The audit office said the failure to comply with legislative procurement thresholds undermined transparency, value for money and the integrity of the council procurement process.

The same audit found TCC did not perform independent cross-checks on related party disclosures of interest forms completed by councillors and key management personnel.

"The process currently relies entirely on employees and elected members to self-declare related interests," the report read.

TCC told the audit office it would implement a more robust process to review and verify related party declarations.

TCC has an annual budget of more than $900 million, but it will soon become a billion-dollar budget as the largest city in northern Australia continues to grow.

Council distrust

Townsville-based James Cook University policy and politics lecturer Liam Moore said the TCC audit could further challenge the public's trust in the local government.

The electorate overwhelmingly voted for change at a mayoral by-election at the weekend, which saw former KAP state MP Nick Dametto claim victory.

"Events like this are not ideal, and they might provoke a little more distrust from the electorate in what they think of Townsville City Council," Dr Moore said.

"[The electorate] wants to see … these public institutions complying with the rules, spending money wisely and [with] the right processes in place."

In a statement, a TCC spokesperson said the contract breach was identified by the council before a further purchase order and the council notified the audit office.

"The scope of works was able to be redefined and the final contract amount was approximately $120,000," the spokesperson said.

title: More than 350 SA schools detect sand linked to asbestos scare
text:
South Australia's education chief has left open the option of removing all coloured sand products from public schools regardless of their brand, as the number of sites that have reported stocking items linked to an asbestos scare climbs above 350.

At about 140 of those schools and preschools — a full list of which has been posted on the Education Department's website — the sand has been reported as "loose", but the department said it had already been removed from several sites.

Asbestos expert says coloured sand poses 'very low risk' Dozens of schools remain closed in the ACT, Tasmania and South Australia today as the clean-up and disposal of potentially asbestos-laced coloured sand continues. What risk does it actually pose?

According to the department, the sand has either been secured at a majority of the locations or has been confined to isolated areas.

"The sand's in a pot, in a bag, it's safe, it's away, and we'll get to those sites and collect that," chief executive Martin Westwell told ABC Radio Adelaide.

"The other sites are sites where perhaps the sand is out, maybe even kind of stuck up on the wall, on artwork or out on a table somewhere, and the advice from SafeWork has been to get asbestos removal contractors to get in and remove that and that's exactly what we're doing."

Our Lady of La Vang school at Flinders Park is one of two Catholic Education sites that has temporarily closed. (ABC News: Daniel Taylor)

Catholic Education yesterday said it had temporarily closed two schools in Adelaide to allow for deep cleaning, but Mr Westwell said there was currently no reason for public schools to follow suit.

"I know that some sites have got particular issues just with the clean-up and how do you get it out of the sites, perhaps if it's spread around a lot, and that might be why some of those other schools are closing, just to help with the clean-up," he said.

" But the risk is incredibly low, and if I thought that it wasn't — if I thought that the risk was higher and that there was a real challenge for students' health — I'd close schools, I wouldn't hesitate. "

Two Catholic schools remain closed

On Saturday, the department revealed coloured sand products linked to the contamination scare had been identified at more than 100 sites.

Mr Westwell said the growing list of schools that have reported finding the impacted sand products on their premises reflected the number of products themselves, with major retailers joining the ACCC in issuing recalls.

Asked whether there were grounds for "removing all of this kind of product, no matter what the brand is, given these concerns", Mr Westwell said that possibility would be looked at.

"With the recall that we see now I don't think there's going to be much of this … coloured sand, this play sand, left in our sites anyway," he said.

"We'll certainly have a look at that, but what we're doing at the moment is making sure that we're responding to the advice from the ACCC and SafeWork."

In a statement on Monday, Catholic Education said it had temporarily closed Our Lady of La Vang Special School at Flinders Park and St Patrick's Special School at Dulwich.

St Patrick's Special School at Dulwich has also closed. (ABC News: Daniel Taylor)

A spokesperson confirmed the sites remained closed today.

"A deep clean has been arranged. Students, staff and families are unable to re-enter identified learning spaces until this has happened," the spokesperson said.

"In separate cases in our schools, if there is any loose sand identified, we have made appropriate arrangements to re-locate students safely to other learning spaces while cleaning is undertaken."

Education Minister Blair Boyer said the situation at the two Catholic schools necessitated closure.

"They've done that because they didn't have space that they could move students — and special schools can be a bit more complex," he said.

"They didn't have space to move students so that the areas where the sand had been loose could be deep-cleaned."

Education authorities say there is no reason to close public schools, but they are monitoring the situation. (ABC News: Daniel Taylor)

Mr Boyer told ABC News Breakfast he was not surprised by the "high number" of schools that had reported finding the recalled coloured sand products, given their popularity.

While he acknowledged the ACT had implemented broader school closures, Mr Boyer said circumstances were different in South Australia.

"Although, if there are circumstances where a school needed to be shut to deep-clean to take place, then of course that is what we would do," he said.

"I think there's a real question to be asked here about how this stuff got in in the first place."

title: Boxing is no game, despite Jake Paul's increasingly dangerous charade
text:
If nothing else, there is one indisputable truth about the sport of boxing — it is not a sport that you play.

"You don't play boxing," five-weight world champion Sugar Ray Leonard once said, a sentiment similar to those echoed by countless fighters and pundits before and since.

"You really don't. You play golf, you play tennis, but you don't play boxing."

The risks are enormous, and the examples of just how catastrophically things can turn inside the squared circle are countless.

It's why Jake Paul's announced fight against Anthony Joshua is so reckless that foolish doesn't cover it.

Even to call it idiotic is kind.

Jake Paul may have bitten off more than he can chew. (Getty Images: Leonardo Fernandez)

The YouTuber-turned-upstart boxer has announced that he will step into the ring against the 2012 Olympic super heavyweight gold medallist and two-time unified heavyweight champion of the world at the Kaseya Center in Miami on December 19.

Boxing's propensity to plumb the depths of moral ambiguity is not new, and its shady and objectionable quest for ever-larger purses at the expense of genuine sporting merit is a constant-yet-accepted gripe among fans.

But this has the potential to be another — largely avoidable — disaster played out in front of a gore-hungry public who care little for the outcome beyond baying for the sight of blood.

Boxing is dangerous.

Men and women have died in the ring.

Even if dramatic, instant catastrophes are mercifully rare, the well-documented long-term effect of having one's brain pounded by another person's fists in the name of entertainment means that those catastrophic outcomes are almost inevitable one way or another.

Jake Paul beat up 58-year-old Mike Tyson in Netflix's first boxing show. (Getty Images: Al Bello)

As was the fear ahead of Paul's shambolic fight against Mike Tyson — a fear that was thankfully not realised — the prospect of serious damage being done is very, very real.

Only this time, it's Paul in the firing line.

He alluded to the fact that this was not a game when announcing the fight.

"This isn't an AI simulation. This is Judgement Day," the 28-year-old said.

Yet the bravado of a man not entirely sure what he is getting into immediately shone through, perhaps suggesting that he believes he is, in fact, in some kind of glorified show in which he is the undoubted star.

"When I beat Anthony Joshua, every doubt disappears, and no-one can deny me the opportunity to fight for a world title," he said.

"To all my haters, this is what you wanted."

Joshua, without question, marks the toughest opponent of Paul's ring career.

Anthony Joshua is a different calibre of fighter to all of Jake Paul's previous opponents. (Getty Images: Richard Pelham)

A professional record of 28-4, with 25 KOs — all in the monstrous heavyweight division — is one thing. A massive, 198-centimetre, musclebound frame and a boxing pedigree built from numerous battles against the world's very best is another.

The only stipulation is that Joshua must come in at under a catchweight of 245 pounds (111.1 kilograms) — the first time he has had to fight under a limit in his career.

He most recently weighed in at 114.3kg for his fight against Daniel Dubois. Paul has never weighed in at more than 103kg for a fight and most often fights under the cruiserweight limit of 90kg.

Both fighters will wear regulation 10-ounce gloves for the eight, three-minute rounds.

Paul has a pro record of 12-1 with 7 KOs. The pedigree of his opponents is not quite of the same calibre, a collection carefully curated combatants for maximum exposure and minimal risk — if there is such a thing in boxing.

Jake Paul has carefully selected all of his opponents thus far. (Getty Images: Michael Reaves)

Yes, on paper, former world champion Tyson posed a formidable opponent. But the uncomfortable sight of the then-58-year-old former baddest man on the planet seemingly struggle to muster the power to punch through a paper bag highlighted a different reality.

After Jake Paul mocked Mike Tyson, he uttered four words that nobody wanted to hear Mike Tyson's return to the ring played out exactly as everyone expected as the once-feared baddest man in boxing was reduced to an impotent husk. It's why he cannot be allowed to enter the ring again.

Aside from Tyson, Paul's opposition has mostly consisted of out-of-shape MMA fighters and, earlier in his career, woefully under-prepared basketball players.

His one defeat came against an actual, active boxer-turned reality TV star, Tommy Fury.

But Joshua is a different kettle of fish.

Yes, the 36-year-old is on the inexorable slide towards retirement and has suffered four career-defining defeats in his last six world title bouts, including a devastating defeat against fellow Brit Daniel Dubois 14 months ago.

But fighting Paul should be beneath him. Stepping into the ring with someone so obviously out of his class will not harm Joshua's considerable ring legacy among the British sporting public — unless he loses, that is.

Daniel Dubois destroyed Anthony Joshua in their IBF world title fight in September, 2024. (Getty Images: Richard Pelham)

Which is the biggest issue.

Joshua can't afford to take this lightly. He has to make a statement.

The Briton's threat to "break the internet over Jake Paul's face" is not an idle one.

Rising British heavyweight Moses Itauma summed it up succinctly on BBC Sport.

"He [Paul] just needs to weigh the outcomes," said Itauma, who is one of Joshua's training partners.

"I dunno, 50 million [versus] my health, cars and watches [versus] can't say my name.

"Is it worth it?"

Financially, of course, this will be worth it.

Both boxers will expect to rake in tens of millions from what will likely be one of the most-watched sporting events of the year and certainly the highest-rated boxing event.

Millions of people watched Jake Paul's fight against Mike Tyson. (Getty Images: Sportsfile/Stephen McCarthy)

Set to be shown on Netflix on December 19, the event will likely achieve similar numbers to the streaming network's first boxing show — Paul's unsettling bout with the shadow of a man who used to be Tyson.

That was the most-streamed sporting event in history, peaking at 65 million live concurrent streams and drawing an estimated 108 million average live viewers worldwide.

As farcical as Paul's victory over Tyson was, the interest shows there is a sizeable market in it, for a sport that sometimes struggles to get the mainstream attention it used to enjoy in its 1980s heyday.

And, despite the clear issues with that contest and others he has arranged for himself, Paul has made his mark on the sport in more ways than just fighting.

His promotion company, Most Valuable Promotions, is the driver behind the blockbuster women's showdowns between Amanda Serrano and Katie Taylor, earning two sporting legends the sort of purse money for their two groundbreaking bouts that their male counterparts regularly command.

Jake Paul (centre) has helped give women's boxing a far larger platform than it has previously enjoyed. (Getty Images: Sportsfile/Stephen McCarthy)

A staunch advocate for women's sport, Paul backed out of fighting former lightweight world champion Gervonta Davis — which was, in itself, a ludicrous proposition anyway based on that fact that the 165cm-tall Davis has a fighting weight of less than 60kg, while Paul would typically weigh in at 90kg — after Davis was named in a lawsuit by his former partner.

Paul, who described Davis as "an actual walking human piece of garbage", said he "didn't want to give this woman abuser a platform to grow his fans and to grow his bank account".

"My company champions women, " he said.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

So what of this fight?

Dangerous. Yes.

Foolhardy? Of course.

Compelling?

"Is it a bit of a circus? Yeah, absolutely," former WBA lightweight champion Anthony Crolla told BBC Sport.

"I think it's an insane situation.

"It will be a very dangerous fight.

"If there were some kind of injuries inflicted on Jake Paul, then there would be a lot of people who would have to answer big questions.

"Anybody who knows boxing can't allow this to be built up like it's a serious fight."

And yet …

"I think it's crazy, but will I watch it? Probably," Crolla said.

He is not alone. The Netflix show will no doubt do enormous numbers and legitimise what should only ever be the wildest fever dream of a fight.

Boxing is not a game.

Let's hope it's not game over.

title: Tributes flow after death of Paralympic champion Paige Greco
text:
Heartfelt tributes from across the Australian sporting landscape have flooded social media following the death of Paralympic and world champion para-cyclist Paige Greco.

Greco, 28, died at her Adelaide home on Sunday after "experiencing a sudden medical episode".

A statement on behalf of the Greco family, released by AusCycling on Monday, announced Paige's death.

Greco won Australia's first gold medal of the 2020 Tokyo Games, triumphing in the women's C1-C3 3,000m individual pursuit, setting a new world record.

Paralympic gold medal winner Paige Greco dies, aged 28 Australian Paralympian Paige Greco, who won Australia's first gold medal of the 2020 Tokyo Paralympic Games, has died aged 28.

Most recently, the Australian competed at October's Para-cycling Track World Championships in Brazil.

Para-cyclist Tara Neyland was a teammate of Greco's in Brazil, winning three gold medals.

Neyland described Greco as the "warmest, kindest, most compassionate, selfless and brightest soul".

"Thank you for being the best roomie and an even better friend," Neyland wrote.

"My heart is broken. You will be sorely missed."

Greco achieved her dream of competing at a Paralympic Games, winning one gold and two bronze medals in Tokyo. (Reuters: Lisi Niesner)

Erin Rowell was another teammate of Greco's at the Para-cycling Track World Championships.

In her tribute, Rowell said it was an "honour" to have been a teammate with Greco.

"There's a space here that can't be filled, a quiet reminder of the kind, genuine soul you were," Rowell wrote.

"It was an honour to ride alongside you and to share this journey as teammates.

"You brought warmth, calm, and a goodness that lifted everyone around you."

Fellow para-cyclist Alistair Donohoe wrote on social media: "A true blessing to have known and a joy to be around. One of the kindest souls to have ever lived and to be forever missed."

Sporting prowess

Greco started her sporting career as a runner in para-athletics, attempting to make the Australian team for the 2016 Paralympic Games in Rio de Janeiro.

She switched to para-cycling and took the sport by storm, breaking three world records and winning gold in the women's C3 3,000m individual pursuit and the C3 500m time trial at the 2019 Para-cycling Track World Championships.

Later that year, Greco would claim a road cycling world championship in the C3 time trial, and placed fifth in the road race.

In 2021, Greco achieved her dream of participating in a Paralympics, winning gold in the women's C1-C3 3,000m individual pursuit, setting a new world record. Greco won two more bronze medals at those Games.

Greco was then awarded a Medal of the Order of Australia for services to sport in 2022.

Loading...

Australia's chef de mission from those Tokyo Games, Kate McLoughlin, said Greco was one of the most beloved members of the team.

"On the track she was unbelievable, but off the track she was someone that would walk into a room and just light it up," McLoughlin said.

"She was just a joy to have on the team; a kind, considerate, very quiet person but turned it on when it came to that athletic performance.

"She was just incredible, so she'll be sorely missed by the entire Australian Paralympic family."

Cycling great Anna Meares, Australia's chef de mission for the Paris 2024 and Los Angeles 2028 Games, said the death of Greco would be felt widely.

Loading Instagram content

"Thank you for all you stood for, achieved and how you did it while you were here," Meares wrote.

"Your loss is felt hard. You made your impact.

"Love to your family, friends and those in the cycling, Paracycling, Paralympic and sport communities. So sorry we've lost you."

Greco's death was felt away from para-cycling.

Stream End Game with Tony Armstrong on ABC iview Tony Armstrong tackles Australia's overdue reckoning with racism in sport with the help of some of its biggest sports stars.

Distance runner Jaryd Clifford, a three-time Paralympic medallist, knew Greco for more than a decade.

Clifford paid tribute to Greco's perseverance and warm nature.

"One of the nicest people I've ever met," Clifford wrote.

"From our first AIS camp in 2012 to the Paralympic Games, Paige was as tough as they come with one of the best smiles in sport. Rest easy Paige."

Greco suffered a high-speed crash during a time trial in Italy in 2023, where she suffered a severe concussion, broken nose, and also lost a tooth.

Her road to recovery was done with the Queensland Academy of Sport (QAS) in Brisbane.

Greco missed out on qualifying for the Paris Paralympic Games in 2024, but completed a return to international success in 2025 by winning bronze in the UCI World Cup time trial in Ostend, Belgium.

At the 2025 UCI Para-cycling Road World Championships in August, also in Belgium, Greco would add another bronze medal to her list of achievements in the road race.

Last week, QAS announced Greco was moving back to Adelaide and would join the South Australia Sports Institute.

In the wake of her death, a statement from QAS described Greco as an inspiration both on the bike and away from competitive cycling.

"Paige was an exceptional athlete and an extraordinary person," the QAS statement read.

"Her sporting achievements on the world stage inspired so many, but it was her kindness, warmth and positivity that left the deepest impression on everyone who had the privilege of knowing her.⁣"

Loading Instagram content

In a statement released on Monday announcing her death, Greco's family said Paige had enriched the lives of those who knew and loved her.

"Paige meant everything to us. Her kindness, her determination and her warmth touched our family every single day," Natalie Greco, Paige's mother, wrote on behalf of their family.

"She brought so much joy and pride into our lives, and the pain of her passing is something we will carry forever.

"While we are devastated by her loss, we are incredibly proud of the person she was and the way she represented Australia.

"As a family, we are deeply grateful for the support shown by so many people connected to Paige, including her teammates and friends. Paige cherished the connections she made through her sport, and we take comfort in knowing how widely she was loved."

title: Weather hampers rescue of hikers stranded on Tasmania's Mount Anne
text:
In short:

Two bushwalkers aged in their 20s called Triple Zero on Monday evening after worsening weather meant they were unable to continue their journey.

Attempts to reach the women were not successful because of the weather conditions, including winds exceeding 100 kilometres per hour and heavy snowfall.

What's next?

Rescue efforts are continuing as weather conditions allow.

title: 'Don't panic': Asbestos expert says coloured sand poses 'very low risk'
text:
Dozens of schools remain closed in the ACT, Tasmania and South Australia today as the clean-up and disposal of coloured sand, feared to be laced with asbestos, continues across the country.

Each state and territory has taken a different approach to dealing with the recalled products, with the ACT requiring licensed asbestos removalists to be called in to schools, while some other jurisdictions are advising that the products be double-bagged and disposed of according to instructions.

The asbestos that has been found in some coloured sand products is naturally occurring, and advice from officials and experts so far has been that the risk of exposure is low.

What kind of asbestos are we dealing with?

Tremolite and chrysotile asbestos have been found in testing of different coloured sand products by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) and WorksafeACT.

The testing prompted the ACCC to last week recall the products, and, since then, four more products sold by Kmart and Target have been pulled from the shelves.

Molecular pharmacologist Ian Musgrave from the University of Adelaide said the forms of asbestos found in the sand were less likely to create fibres than other more hazardous types like blue asbestos.

Asbestos fibres seen under an electron microscope. (Getty Images: Callista Images)

Chrysotile, also known as white asbestos, is the most common type of asbestos and is the main form used commercially.

Tremolite is relatively rare, and can be found in mineral talc and vermiculite deposits.

"It still can form fibres, but typically it's found in non-fibrous forms and it's less likely to form fibres that can be breathed in," Dr Musgrave said.

"The ACCC investigation found that the material that was found in these sands weren't the ones that can be easily lofted into the air and breathed in."

What is the concern then?

All types of asbestos can cause mesothelioma and asbestosis.

Kadink decorative sand was among the first brands of coloured sand to be recalled. (Supplied: ACCC)

“All asbestos is hazardous but the amount of hazard is different,” Dr Musgrave said.

Although the material detected in the sand is less likely than other forms of asbestos to form fibres, authorities are not taking any chances.

"The damage caused by asbestos is due to these fibres getting breathed in [and] getting into the cells," Dr Musgrave said.

"Because the cells can't break them down, they generate oxidative stress which can cause damage to the lung and can also result in lung cancer."

What risk does the coloured sand pose?

Asbestos has not been found in all of the sand that has been analysed, and where it has been found, it has been at trace levels.

"It's fairly low level and also the material is in a form that it's not easily breathed in," Dr Musgrave said.

"This is a form which doesn't easily form fibres and it's not forming fibres which can be lofted into the air and breathed in by kids.

" So unless you've got an industrial sand milling machine in your school it's very unlikely that your children will be exposed to fibres that can be breathed in and cause disease. "

Kmart and Target have recalled four coloured sand products over potential asbestos contamination. (Supplied: MBIE)

Dr Musgrave said the risk for asbestos-induced disease was related to both how much and how long a person was exposed.

“Given that this has been discovered recently, it's likely that exposure to this material hasn't been long and because it's the form it doesn't easily form particles you can breathe in, and it's also in trace levels, the exposure levels are quite low," he said.

"So the risk of of any disease from this exposure is also low.

" It's not zero. There will never be a zero risk. But the risk is very low. "

Dr Musgrave said his advice to parents whose children attend affected schools was "don't panic".

What's happening in each jurisdiction today?

Twenty-five public schools will remain closed across Canberra today, with another 16 partially closed.

Fifty-one ACT schools, which were previously closed, have fully reopened today.

Asbestos removal teams are working to clean up and dispose of coloured sand products in Canberra schools. (ABC News: Matt Roberts)

More than 300 education sites in South Australia have now reported the use of coloured sand that may contain asbestos.

The Department of Education said licensed asbestos contractors began removing the recalled product from its sites yesterday.

It said the risk was low and was being managed in line with national standards and advice from SafeWork SA.

Meanwhile, Catholic schools Our Lady of La Vang Special School in Flinders Park and St Patrick's Special School in Dulwich have temporarily closed due to the identification of sand products.

Catholic Education South Australia said a deep clean had been arranged and students, staff and families were unable to re-enter some learning spaces until this had happened.

Six Tasmanian non-government schools are closed today, while another six are partially closed. No public schools are closed.

But Tasmania's Education Union is calling on the Education Department to consider closing schools.

Twenty-five schools across Canberra are closed today. (ABC News: Mark Moore)

No schools have been closed in Victoria, although 300 schools and more than 600 early childhood services have been identified as using the recalled products.

"Schools and early childhood services have been provided with updated guidance, including safe-handling instructions for the craft sand. Government schools have also been provided with advice on how to report products to be collected for disposal."

On Monday, WA Premier Roger Cook confirmed 76 schools in WA had been found with coloured sand products that were recalled.

In a statement, the Queensland Department of Education said it was working closely with all state schools "that may be impacted by the coloured sand recall".

"We do not anticipate there will be any state school closures this week and all schools are open as normal today. We are working to ensure continuity of education for all students," it said.

Concern over lack of uniformity between jurisdictions

The Asbestos Disease Society of Australia is concerned about the different state and territory responses to potential asbestos exposure.

Queensland parents question asbestos sand dilemma Queensland parents are divided over the nationwide recall of coloured sand that may have traced of asbestos.

Society head Melita Markey said varied state regulations could create a patchy national response.

"Different agencies get together and meet and they come up with what they consider to be a good national approach, but then it's all up to the individual states whether they adopt it," she said.

"The federal asbestos eradication agency came out with a strategic plan. Not every state signed on to that immediately and then they could pick or choose what parts they adopted."

Ms Markey also urged Australia's education sector to be more proactive in identifying and removing other forms of asbestos from schools.

"We're focusing on something that's very immediate, but what about the long-term effects of children in these ageing, deteriorating schools around Australia — ageing and deteriorating roofs, putting asbestos fibres through the gutters, washing it down around the grounds," she said.

"Let's start looking at the bigger picture of removing that."

title: Rio Tinto to slash alumina production in Queensland, impacting 180 jobs
text:
Rio Tinto has revealed it will slash alumina production at its Queensland refinery by 40 per cent, following concerns about the future viability of the facility.

The company said it would reduce production at Gladstone's Yarwun Alumina Refinery from October next year, which would allow it to extend the site's operations until 2035.

At current production rates, the Yarwun tailings facility was predicted to reach capacity in 2031.

"This curtailment will allow another four years to explore and develop technical solutions that could further extend the refinery's life," it said.

Rio Tinto's alumina refinery near Gladstone is exploring hydrogen power. (ABC News: Kylie Gillespie)

The cut will reduce annual alumina production by about 1.2 million tonnes and impact about 180 jobs at the refinery.

Rio Tinto general manager for bauxite and alumina Tim McDougall said the company was not seeking government support for a new tailings development.

"This decision is about the economic viability of the tailings facility, it is not about government policy and we're very focused on solving that ourselves," he said.

Redeployment planning underway

Mr McDougall said every effort would be made to find opportunities for people who want to stay in Gladstone, through Queensland Alumina Limited (QAL) and Boyne Smelters.

"We have a long lead time which allows us to work through the changes … this will give us time to talk with our people, to understand their preferences and manage this change," he said.

"As required, we're also very open to looking at opportunities more broadly in Queensland and also in Australia."

Rio Tinto's aluminium Pacific operations managing director Armando Torres said the company had investigated whether it could develop a second tailings facility at Yarwun, but it was not economically viable.

"Reducing production from October 2026 enables us to continue alumina production until 2035 and trial pathways to secure the longer-term future of Yarwun," Mr Torres said.

"It is a difficult but necessary decision that preserves future options for the site and supports continued economic contribution."

Rio Tinto says it is exploring options to further extend the refinery's life. (Reuters: David Gray)

Mr Torres said Rio Tinto remained committed to its alumina and aluminium operations in Gladstone.

The company said there would be no impact to its customers or other operations, with bauxite mines and aluminium smelters to continue to operate at full capacity.

'I trust they will do the right thing'

Gladstone Regional Council Mayor Matt Burnett said the announcement was concerning, but he was hopeful there was a future for the site.

"If Rio Tinto wanted to close Yarwun early, they would go full steam ahead towards 2031," Cr Burnett said.

" That isn't the case, and they are actively exploring new technologies to keep the facility open and viable. "

Cr Burnett said the company had been a long-term employer in Gladstone.

"I trust they will do the right thing by the people and workers of Gladstone, who have supported their operations since 1967," he said.

Alumina is used as a feedstock in smelters to create aluminium and has a wide range of other industrial uses.

The Yarwun site currently employs about 725 people and produces about 3 million tonnes of alumina per year.

It comes less than two months after Rio Tinto announced it would potentially close the Gladstone Power Station six years earlier than expected.

title: How to watch the ARIA awards ceremony
text:
The best and the brightest Australian music stars will be coming together for the ARIA awards this week.

Here's what you need to know about the ceremony.

What are the ARIAs?

It's an Australian music awards ceremony — the one with the really pointy silver trophies.

ARIA stands for the Australian Recording Industry Association.

But an aria is also a musical term, with the Macquaire Dictionary defining it as "an elaborate melody for a single voice, with accompaniment, in an opera, oratorio, etc …"

This year, the ceremony is being held at Sydney's Hordern Pavilion.

Triple j Breakfast presenter Concetta Caristo and Nova's Tim Blackwell will be hosting the awards.

Concetta Caristo will host the ceremony along with Tim Blackwell. (Supplied: Monica Pronk)

When are the ARIA awards?

Tomorrow afternoon.

Where can I watch the ARIA awards?

The ceremony is being streamed live on Paramount+ from 5pm AEDT.

You'll be able to watch the ceremony on free-to-air television on Channel 10 later that night, with the red-carpet show starting at 7pm AEDT.

As for the actual ceremony itself, the ARIA website just says it'll come on "following Big Brother" instead of giving a specific time.

Who is nominated?

The artist with the most nominations is Ninajirachi, who is up for eight awards.

The full list of the ARIA award nominees All the contenders are hopefuls vying for ARIA Awards glory at the music industry's glitzy ceremony, taking place next month.

Her debut album I Love My Computer has earned her nominations in major categories like Album of the Year, Best Solo Artist, Best Independent and Electronic Release.

All up, there are 29 categories, but here are the nominees for the top three most talked about awards:

Album of the Year

Amyl and The Sniffers – Cartoon Darkness

Missy Higgins – The Second Act

Ninajirachi – I Love My Computer

RÜFÜS DU SOL – Inhale / Exhale

Thelma Plum – I'm Sorry, Now Say It Back

Best Solo Artist

BARKAA – Big Tidda

Dom Dolla – DREAMIN’

Kylie Minogue – Tension II

Mallrat – Light hit my face like a straight right

Missy Higgins – The Second Act

Ninajirachi – I Love My Computer

Paul Kelly – Fever Longing Still

The Kid LAROI – How Does It Feel?

Thelma Plum – I'm Sorry, Now Say It Back

Young Franco – it's Franky baby!

Best Group

Amyl and The Sniffers – Cartoon Darkness

Folk Bitch Trio – Now Would Be A Good Time

Hilltop Hoods – Fall From The Light

Royel Otis – hickey

RÜFÜS DU SOL – Inhale / Exhale

Who is performing?

British singer Oliva Dean is this year's major international act.

Olivia Dean will perform at the ARIA awards. (Supplied: Laneway Presents)

But there will also be performances from local artists including:

Alex Lahey

Anna Ryan

Baker Boy

G Flip

Janet English

Keli Holiday

Kita Alexander

Missy Higgins

Neve Van Boxsel

Thelma Plum

Touch Sensitive

You Am I

Young Franco

On top of this, all five nominees for Best Soul/R&B Release will perform with a 15-piece band, so expect a super set from:

title: Outdated Samsung software behind failed Triple Zero call death, telco says
text:
TPG Telecom says a Sydney customer died after outdated software blocked a Samsung phone from making Triple Zero (000) calls.

The telco said in a statement it was informed of the incident involving a person using a Lebara service on a Samsung device on November 13 by NSW Ambulance yesterday.

TPG Telecom said its mobile network was operational and no outages had occurred.

"Early investigations indicate that the failed calls were due to the customer's Samsung device operating on software that was not compatible with making Triple Zero calls on the network," the company said in a statement.

" Samsung recently identified that certain, older devices required a software update to enable Triple Zero functionality on TPG Telecom's mobile network. "

The telco said when it became aware of issues with these handsets on its network, it told customers "to urgently update affected devices".

A number of older Samsung devices are listed on the company's website as needing to be replaced or updated. (ABC News: Jack Ailwood)

"Handsets not updated are blocked after a period of 28-35 days from the first contact to the customer, as required under new regulations," the company said.

"The most recent communications to customers with impacted devices was sent on 7 November."

Samsung said on its website it had identified older mobile devices that do not "correctly connect to an alternative mobile network to make Triple Zero calls when the user's primary network is not available".

It lists dozens of devices that need to be updated or replaced to make sure they work reliably during an emergency.

It said newer model phones were not affected.

TPG boss offers condolences, urges action

TPG Telecom said its mobile network was operational and no outages had occurred. (ABC News: Jack Ailwood)

TPG Telecom managing director and CEO Inaki Berroeta said customer safety was the company's "highest priority" and urged users of affected devices to update their software or replace them.

"This is a tragic incident, and our condolences and thoughts are with the individual's family and loved ones," he said.

"Access to emergency services is critical.

"We urge all customers with outdated software to replace or update their devices without delay to ensure they can reach Triple Zero in an emergency."

TPG Telecom said the communications minister, NSW Government, Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA), Triple Zero Custodian and other relevant government and regulatory bodies had been notified of the incident.

Communications Minister Anika Wells said the "tragic situation" would be investigated.

"TPG's compliance with the Emergency Call Service Determination will be rigorously assessed by ACMA," she said in a statement.

ACMA said in a statement it would investigate whether there had been any non-compliance with the Triple Zero rules and enforcement action taken if any was found.

"Under rules introduced in 2024, telecommunications providers must notify their customers where the provider identifies that the customer's device may not be able to connect to triple zero and then take action to block those devices from their networks," it said.

title: Westpac keeps regional branches for another three years
text:
One of Australia's largest banks has committed to retaining regional branches for another three years, following a federal inquiry into the impact of branch closures on country towns.

On Monday, Westpac announced it would extend its moratorium on bank closures in the regions from 2027 to 2030.

The company also said it would pilot a new Community Banking Service and implement ways to attract staff to smaller areas.

But the chair of the Senate committee, which headed the inquiry, said the recommendations handed down last year had gone largely unanswered by the federal government.

Commitment to the regions

In 2024, a Senate committee report into the impact of bank closures in regional Australia was handed down.

After receiving more than 600 submissions and touring the country to hear the concerns of local businesses and communities, the inquiry provided eight recommendations to the federal government.

More than a year later, Westpac announced a host of new initiatives to boost regional branches, including a graduate program enticing staff to the regions.

Chief executive Anthony Miller said it came after a full review into how the company serviced rural Australia.

"We want to make sure these [regional] areas have access to the services they need to prosper and grow," he said.

Regional Chamber of Commerce and Industry WA chief executive Kitty Prodonovich said it was good to see the major bank respond to the grievances raised.

Kitty Prodonovich says a holistic approach is needed to ensure gaps are filled in regional banking services. (ABC News: Julian Robins)

"My hope is that they've listened and that people in regional WA aren't going to have another service close down or taken away," she said.

"They do have quite a big regional footprint in WA, but I think one of the bigger issues is how do we look at those services that are getting withdrawn, and how do we make sure something else is in their place.

"One of the concerns we have about it is often it seems to be a decision [to close] is made from far away by people who haven't worked, lived or done business in regional WA."

Recommendations still not accepted

Queensland Senator Matt Canavan, who chaired the regional banking inquiry, welcomed Westpac's commitment, but said the federal government still needed to step up.

"It's good to see there's been a moratorium on bank closures at least from the major banks, and I welcome Westpac doing this," he said.

"The downside is we need to try and replace financial services being lost in those towns where regional branches have already closed.

"Our report had a number of recommendations that the government still has not responded to, despite them being made more than a year ago now."

Matt Canavan chaired the inquiry. (ABC News: Ian Cutmore)

Senator Canavan said if banks had to close branches, there should be other solutions offered for regional communities.

"[Banks] should only be doing closures in a very careful way, making sure people are not simply left with no other solution," he said.

"That hasn't been happening, and so one of our recommendations was that it needs to be forced by the government, but we haven't gotten a response on that yet.

" I think there needs to be a role of government here to fill in these gaps, just like we do with telecommunications or education services. Financial services are essential too. "

Treasurer Jim Chalmers welcomed Westpac's announcement.

"This is welcome news and builds on the commitments we secured from the big banks in February to keep services available in regional Australia," he said.

"Westpac's announcement today reflects the kinds of commitment we want to see in regional Australia … and we encourage other banks to follow Westpac's lead."

title: Live: 'Unlikely' rates will move in 2026, CBA boss tells hearing
text:
Always love reading the take of Shane Oliver (chief economist, AMP) on the economy.

Here's prices to earnings....

And here are some of Shane's words:

"First, shares are expensive. This is nothing new but is clearly evident in relatively high price to earnings multiples. The forward price to earnings ratio on US shares is at 23.5 times, not far below the 1999-2000 tech boom high. The PE on Australian shares is well above its tech boom high despite a recent fall.

"And valuations are a poor guide to timing market movements. That said, high PEs and the low equity risk premium compared to much of the last twenty years warn of a slower return potential ahead and provide less of a buffer should things go wrong.

"Second, shares have had several years of strong gains, with the last bear market in global shares being in 2022. Shares did have sharp falls into April this year on Trump's tariffs, but the falls were less than 20% and were quickly reversed. Over the last 3 years US shares have returned 23%pa, global shares 21%pa and Australian shares 13%pa. History warns that after a run of strong above average years a weaker year and often a bear market can come along.

"Third, there are signs of a bubble forming in AI shares with investor enthusiasm for AI related exposure. Specifically, the Magnificent Seven (Apple, Microsoft, Alphabet, Amazon, Nvidia, Meta and Tesla) have risen more than 30-fold over the last decade dwarfing various other bubbles and they have disproportionately driven the US share market accounting for 50% or more of its gains since 2023."

title: SunCable signs multi-million-dollar agreement with traditional owners
text:
A small Northern Territory town with a shuttered pub, no library and just a single service station could one day be the hub for Australia’s biggest and most ambitious large-scale solar project.

The long-hyped SunCable project is a step closer to reality after a landmark 70-year, multi-million-dollar agreement was signed on Monday in a community on the outskirts of the NT town of Elliott.

The agreement was signed between Janigirulu, Bamayu and the Walanypirri traditional owners, the Northern Land Council, the NT government and SunCable.

Community members watched on as the agreement between SunCable, traditional owners and the Northern Land Council was signed. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

SunCable is planning to build a 12,000 hectare solar farm on Powell Creek Station, south of Elliott.

With the new agreement comes the promise by SunCable – the company backed by billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes – for "multi-generational wealth" to the region’s Aboriginal traditional owners.

Bamayu traditional owner Glenys Grieve said the project could benefit future generations.

"This project goes for 70 years, and is something we probably won't see out, but our children, our grandchildren, will all benefit from this project going ahead," she said.

Matthew Ryan says engagement with native title holders and the NLC is "key for economic development" in the NT. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

Northern Land Council (NLC) chairman, Matthew Ryan, said the agreement "represents genuine partnership between big business and traditional owners".

"Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory are open for business to grow the territory," he said.

He said it gave a chance for Elliott to be the hub for the region, as the project comes to fruition.

The agreement marked the culmination of three years of negotiations between SunCable and around 200 traditional owners, with more than 70 meetings taking place across the vast region.

Ryan Willemsen-Bell says his company's goal is "to deliver reliable, cost-effective renewable electricity" across the NT and South-East Asia. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

SunCable’s chief executive Ryan Willemsen-Bell, who travelled to Elliott for the milestone, promised it would offer "long-term community benefits that will extend well beyond the life of this project".

"The renewable energy project that we embark on today is one of the largest of its kind in the region, with a projected life span of over 70 years," he said.

"It will harness the power of the Sun to generate cost-effective large-scale renewable energy, positioning the Northern Territory as a leader in the clean energy transition.

"And the Barkly, where we stand today, is at the heart of this."

The agreement proposes the solar farm be built on Powell Creek Station near Elliott, about six-and-a-half hours south-east of Katherine (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

SunCable pledges energy generation by late 2020s

SunCable, which was founded in 2018, has been working for years to build its solar farm in the NT outback, despite facing financial challenges.

Mr Willemsen-Bell said from the outset the goal had been to harness the NT's solar resource "to deliver reliable, cost-effective renewable electricity" across the territory and South-East Asia.

Solar farm proposed for Muckaty Station An ambitious outback solar project could soon grow even bigger, with plans lodged to build a new solar farm in remote NT.

In Elliott, he confirmed that the company was aiming to be powering parts of the NT in coming years.

"We anticipate that at the end of this decade, we will producing energy here in the Barkly region, and from there we will see further progress into Darwin, and then into South-East Asia," he said.

In 2024, the project was approved by the NT government and later by the then-federal environment minister, Tanya Plibersek, who issued strict conditions about protecting critical habitats and native species.

SunCable said the new agreement with traditional owners would also ensure "cultural knowledge and connections to land will be protected and will continue to be passed down through generations".

title: Australia news LIVE: Wells says latest Triple Zero death will be fully investigated; UN approves Trump’s Gaza peace plan; Jess Wilson makes history as first female Victorian Liberal leader
text:
The Reserve Bank has signaled what it will take for official interest rates to fall further, with the jobs market and consumer spending the key swing factors.

Minutes of the bank’s Melbourne Cup Day meeting, at which it left the cash rate at 3.6 per cent, released today show the discussion among bank board members about how interest rate settings could change.

There’s been a growing consensus the RBA will keep rates steady all through 2026. Commonwealth Bank boss Matt Comyn told a parliamentary hearing this morning he believed a rate cut next year was unlikely.

The RBA minutes showed board members argued there were situations where rates may need to be reduced.

A material weakening of the jobs market is seen as one of the biggest risks, particularly if the private sector starts to struggle.

“[Members] noted the risk that employment growth in the market sector remains soft, which could occur if the uncertain economic outlook reduces firms’ willingness to hire or if an emerging focus on cost-cutting results in lay-offs,” the minutes showed.

A drop-off in the general economy, especially if shoppers become more cautious about their spending, would also put a rate cut back on the agenda.

But, the minutes showed, the bank believes rates could hold steady if the “emerging recovery in demand was stronger than expected” which would itself strengthen the jobs market.

Another risk would be if productivity growth proved weaker than expected. The RBA earlier this year reduced its long-term assumption for productivity growth.

The bank’s monetary policy committee meets once more this year, in early December, with financial markets putting the chance of a rate cut at just 7 per cent.

title: A legendary NFL boss says AFL clubs must follow these eight commandments for success
text:
“I call that a prerequisite. I say that there’s a standard that these players with athletic traits...on whatever field, whatever sport you’re in. “Let’s call them A, B, C and D. If you’re E, you don’t help. Rams quarterback Matthew Stafford. Credit: AP “Once all the players, either are in A, B, C or D category, to me then it’s all intangibles. “So, if you’re an A athlete, but your intangibles are a C, they usually play to a B or a C.

“Intangibles will help you either meet or exceed your expectation.” Stafford’s career was founded on intangibles, as with many quarterbacks. Players who didn’t fit in with teammates, weren’t team-first, were often shunted. “We’ve all been there, we’re like ‘I think we ought to kick those guys off the boat, they’re not helping us.’” In his office, Snead mentioned his friend, Sam Walker, whom the Los Angeles Rams employ as a consultant and who had recently been in Melbourne working with Brad Scott and Essendon on leadership. Zach Merrett and Andrew McGrath Credit: AFL Photos via Getty Images Last summer, Scott, Zach Merrett and Andy McGrath - Merrett’s probable successor as skipper - went to LA to meet with Walker, who specialises in the construction of team ethos and leadership.

Essendon’s cultural issues, exemplified by Merrett’s attempted escape, seemed relevant to another commandment on the wall: “IMMERSE OUR PEOPLE IN THE RAMS WE THEN ME WAY.” “WE” was coloured yellow against blue for emphasis. Here were other striking observations from Snead which hold relevance to the AFL draft (and trading/free agency): 1. Why a gun player can slide in the draft Puka Nacua, a star wide receiver, was drafted at pick No 177, the fifth round of the 2023 draft. Snead said Pacua had been overlooked by all teams in the early rounds because he did not fit the prototype for his position - which was biased to speed.

Nacua, too, was injured in his final college year. “In the draft, let’s call it the higher you get... usually there’s a cleaner profile. That’s just the way the probabilities work. “His game is strength and power, probably bully ball - catch the ball and I’m now going to have to make you tackle me, and a lot of times that’s devalued in the draft. We’ve seen some of the players that fit that profile, they get devalued, because it’s a spacing game, speed, explosiveness. A young Sam Mitchell Credit: Peter Mathew “There was a strategy there. And we could probably get him a little later. Now based on all things considered we should have picked him earlier.” The AFL clubs will all be hoping, no matter the odds, of finding their version of Nacua (188 cm and 96 kilograms), who is his sport’s answer to Chris Grant, James Hird, Sam Mitchell, Tom Stewart and others who were bypassed early in the draft. The knock on Mitchell was that he was small and slow.

Loading 2. Which are the hardest players to assess in the draft and why? A simple answer to this one from Snead: Quarterbacks. Why? “NFL’s the highest level of a video game... The game in college is different to the NFL and the quality is not as good....there’s more space. “In the NFL, there’s hardly any space... Can you, as that QB then, as things [happen], speed up?

In the AFL, the draft record suggests key forwards are harder to identify than midfielders. Key forwards - and some key backs - don’t necessarily replicate junior success in the AFL. Like quarterbacks, they face congestion in the big league. The Rams traded in Stafford, knowing he was a proven commodity, in the same way that the Swans acquired Curnow, and Tony Lockett, Barry Hall and Lance Franklin before him. When did Sydney last draft a quality key forward? “You cut out the risk when you trade for quarterback,” said Snead. Charlie Curnow as a Swan. Credit: Eddie Jim 3. Trading in mature players for draft picks when in the premiership window

Snead follows a method similar to AFL clubs who believe you only give up draft capital when entering contention. One factor he mentioned is seldom raised in the AFL - that of the senior coach also being “in his prime”. The LA Rams win the Super Bowl in 2022. Credit: AP “In the year we won the Super Bowl … we had a lot of players in their prime. “So we used like some of our premium draft picks to make trades, to bring in other players in their prime.

“That might not be the strategy if you’re not there yet.” Stafford was acquired from the Detroit Lions using that formula. “A lot of his teammates were in their prime, the head coach was in his prime. It was like, ‘OK, if we add a QB in his prime’, now you have, at least on paper, a more complete [team]. “If you’re not there and you’re getting there, you might be a little bit heavier [in the] draft.” 4. What to do once a team enters “no man’s land?” No man’s land, as defined by a senior AFL club official (to his board) was neither rebuilding, nor contending (nor the half-way house of “building”). Snead, when this was put to him, liked the concept and spoke as if he’d been in that predicament.

“No man to me is you’ve got to tear it down first. Which is, ‘oh wow, we have to tear this thing down over two seasons.’ That ought to be fun and I’m sure the fans are going to have trust in us, right? Loading “Mine would be, if you’re in no man’s [land], you’ve got to tear it down. That may be you’re a team that’s older, right, and now how to do you move on... I call the rebuilding/building...or I call it remodelling.” Melbourne and Carlton, mired in no man’s land in 2025, would appear to have followed Snead’s formula, to an extent, by trading out Christian Petracca and Clayton Oliver and Charlie Curnow, as Tom De Koning walked as a free agent. Jake Niall travelled to LA as a guest of the Rams.

title: The Age Good Food Guide 2026: Best places to eat and drink in Geelong and the Surf Coast
text:
Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime.

From wine bars to bakeries, pub meals to cocktails, here’s how to spend a delicious few days in this rapidly changing region.

The best place to kick off a culinary journey of Geelong is Pakington Street – a lively stretch of boutiques, restaurants, Victorian-era architecture and cafes tucked down cobblestone alleys. Box Office is a vast warehouse-style space serving Axil coffee and brunch that goes heavy on native Australian ingredients. Hatted restaurant Tulip runs a refined snack-forward menu, while the front bar of the historic Petrel Hotel is alive with fans of well-executed pub dishes ordering hefty chicken schnitties lathered in garlic butter.

Chicken schnitzel with garlic butter at the Petrel Hotel. Duncan Jacob

When it comes to morning pastries, there’s That Place in Belmont for viennoiserie by French-trained pastry chef Ashlea Allen, while the Local serves focaccia sangers, house-made pastries and Everyday coffee from a takeaway

window near the CBD. That queue snaking down Pakington at the Newtown end?

Join it, immediately, and you’ll soon be in the sourdough haven that is Born and Bread (moving to a new location just down the road in January). You’ll want to loosen the purse strings as it’s tricky to choose a favourite, but chilli jam twists and custard-filled pecan buns are top contenders.

Come Saturday evening, Geelong’s Little Malop Street pulses with energy. Get your hands dirty at Nashville-inspired bar The Hot Chicken Project, where spice levels range from mild to the blisteringly hot “evil”. Then, ascend the hidden staircase next door for a nightcap at 18th Amendment, a moody bar that nods to America’s prohibition years with cocktails named Bonnie and Clyde, and Thomas Edison.

title: Victorian Liberal leadership spill LIVE: Jess Wilson takes over state party as Brad Battin accepts defeat
text:
Brad Battin gave members of the media the thumbs-up before today’s parliamentary sitting, which has spiralled into farcical scenes in the last few minutes.

In a clear attempt to stir the Coalition, more than a dozen Labor MPs attempted to give “motions by leave” aimed at the opposition, criticising them over their tax policies.

Brad Battin gives the media the thumbs-up before the parliamentary sitting. Credit: Jason South

Under parliamentary rules, these statements can only be given without objections.

The opposition benches loudly yelled “no” every time an MP rose to speak.

This led to more than a dozen Labor MPs standing up, only to be shouted down with smiles on their faces. Point Cook MP Mathew Hilakari quipped they were the “No-alition”.

Sandringham MP Brad Rowswell fired back, saying the first three people to stand up and criticise the new female leader were male MPs.

title: TPG says person dead after failed Triple Zero call
text:
Loading The Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) said in a statement that it was “gathering information to establish the facts of the matter and will investigate to assess whether there has been any non-compliance with the Triple Zero rules. If any breaches are identified, appropriate enforcement action will be taken. “Public safety and reliable access to emergency services are of paramount importance. Under rules introduced in 2024, telecommunications providers must notify their customers where the provider identifies that the customer’s device may not be able to connect to Triple Zero and then take action to block those devices from their networks.” The tragedy comes just two months after three people died during a major Optus outage in mid-September, when more than 600 calls to Triple Zero emergency services failed to connect. That incident, which lasted more than 90 minutes, prompted a federal government inquiry and led to parliament fast-tracking new legislation to strengthen oversight of emergency calling services. The September Optus outage was the second major Triple Zero failure for the telco in two years. In November 2023, more than 2000 calls to emergency services failed to connect during a 12-hour national network outage, resulting in a $12 million fine from ACMA.

The incidents have shaken public confidence in Australia’s emergency services infrastructure and put intense pressure on both telcos and device manufacturers to ensure Triple Zero access. Communications Minister Anika Wells. Credit: Sitthixay Ditthavong The watchdog disclosed just last month that some older Samsung mobile phones released between 2015 and 2017 could not automatically switch to alternative networks to complete Triple Zero calls. Testing revealed that 71 Samsung models were affected, with 11 requiring replacement and 60 needing software updates. The problem stems from legacy firmware configurations that attempt to route emergency calls through Vodafone’s now-defunct 3G network. When Telstra and Optus networks are unavailable, these devices cannot successfully switch to TPG’s 4G network as a back-up. Wells last month warned that the Samsung phone problems could be “indicative of a broader systemic issue” in Australia’s telecommunications emergency services.

There are tens of thousands of devices nationwide that may be affected by the issue. Some 46,000 devices are thought to be affected across Australia’s three major carriers. TPG identified affected devices last year during preparations for the national shutdown of 3G services and blocked them from its network, sharing information with Telstra and Optus. However, Telstra engineers recently discovered during testing that the same Samsung devices were still attempting to connect Triple Zero calls via Vodafone’s decommissioned 3G infrastructure. “Why this was configured this way is a question for Samsung and Vodafone,” a Telstra spokesman said. Vodafone owner TPG described the issues as related to a “legacy configuration within the devices themselves”. The company identified additional Samsung devices this year requiring software updates, and has been blocking devices that haven’t been upgraded, as required under new regulations. “When TPG Telecom became aware of these handsets on its network, we communicated with customers to urgently update affected devices,” the company said on Tuesday morning. “Handsets not updated are blocked after a period of 28 to 35 days from the first contact to the customer, as required under new regulations.

“The most recent communications to customers with impacted devices was sent on 7 November. These updates are critical to ensure compactibility with emergency services and to protect customer safety.” Under rules that took effect from November 1, telcos must test whether mobile phones can switch to other networks during Triple Zero outages, report failures in real time, and disconnect phone services within 28 to 35 days of notifying customers that their devices cannot connect to emergency services. Loading Parliament last month also passed legislation creating a new Triple Zero Custodian with compliance powers to ensure emergency services remain accessible. The custodian can impose maximum fines of $30 million for breaches of Triple Zero rules – a tenfold increase from previous penalties. The government has also ordered telcos to create separate public registers of Triple Zero outages, though carriers have raised concerns about the technical and cost challenges of real-time reporting. TPG warned that implementing real-time reporting for unplanned outages would “require substantial system changes and cost across our operations”.
